title: Steve Bruce admits doubts over signing Andy Robertson and Harry Maguire before rapid rise of pair
text:

Steve Bruce has revealed the reservations he had about Harry Maguire and Andy Robertson prior to signing the pair for Hull City.

Robertson and Maguire both arrived at the Tigers in 2014 and enjoyed three years at the club before deservedly earning moves to the big time.

Robertson went on to join Liverpool , where he has won the Champions League and played a starring role as Jurgen Klopp's Reds challenge for the Premier League title this season.

Maguire, meanwhile, became the world's most expensive defender this summer when he joined Manchester United in a £80million deal from Leicester , who he joined from Hull.

(Image: Getty Images)

And Bruce, now managing Newcastle in the Premier League, has revealed his doubts over signing the pair - after Stan Ternent, Hull City’s head of recruitment at the time, spotted them.

“I remember Stan’s first calls to me about both Andy and Harry,” Bruce told The Athletic . “He had spotted Andy playing for Dundee United and said he had found Billy Whizz.

“I said, ‘Isn’t Billy Whizz in a comic book?’ But Stan was adamant we had to sign him. He was the same over Harry. Stan was relentless over Harry.

"The thing with Harry is he had been playing for Sheffield United since he was 18 and had something like 150 games under his belt (at age 21). He had also been their Player of the Year three years running.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

“But people looked at him and asked, ‘Is he slow on the turn?’ I’ll admit, I asked the same of Stan when he first came to me about Harry. Stan’s reply was priceless, ‘Well, you were slow on the turn and you did OK.'

“As a manager, there is nothing better than seeing a player you worked with fulfil their potential. You have helped take them forward.

“I did have a chuckle, though, about the first time I saw Andy. It was when he walked into the training ground with his mum. I thought we’d signed a schoolboy. I said to Stan, ‘Are you sure?’ But he was adamant and I trusted his judgment.”
